content: How can I help you today?

I haven't been sleeping well lately. Work has been really stressful, and I can't seem to quiet my mind at night. My thoughts keep racing, and I end up just scrolling on my phone, which I know isn't helping. My partner suggested I talk to someone about it, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like things have been feeling pretty overwhelming for you lately, with work stress and restless nights. It’s great that your partner cares about you and encouraged you to reach out. What’s been on your mind lately when your thoughts start racing at night?

A lot of it is about work. I'm constantly worried about getting fired, especially with how things seem uncertain in the company right now. If that happens, I don’t know how I’d take care of my family or pay the bills. It all just spirals from there, and I can’t stop thinking about it.

That sounds really tough—constantly carrying the weight of worry about your job and your family’s well-being. It makes sense that those thoughts could feel overwhelming and hard to turn off. You clearly care deeply about your family and want to make sure you're there for them. How do you feel these worries have been affecting your daily life besides the trouble sleeping?

Well, I feel like I’m constantly on edge, even during the day. I’m exhausted, but I can’t seem to be present with my partner or my kids. I feel like I’m just going through the motions and not really connecting with them, which makes me feel even worse. It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to get out of it.

It sounds like this cycle has been draining for you, especially since being there for your family is so important to you. Feeling disconnected from them, on top of the stress, seems to be weighing heavily on you. Even though it’s been hard, you’re acknowledging how you’re feeling and taking steps like reaching out today—it shows a lot of strength. What do you think might help shift things, or is that something you’d like to explore together?

I'm not really sure what could help, honestly. I’ve tried staying off my phone at night or telling myself not to think about work, but nothing seems to work. I guess I’m open to exploring ideas, but honestly, it’s hard to believe anything will really make a difference right now.

It sounds like you’ve already tried a couple of things, and it’s frustrating when they don’t feel effective. It’s completely understandable for it to feel hard to believe things can improve when the cycle feels so entrenched. The fact that you’re still open to exploring what might help tells a lot about your determination, even when things feel heavy. What do you think makes it challenging to step away from the stress and racing thoughts, especially at night?

I think it’s just that the thoughts don’t stop—it’s like every time I try to calm down, they get louder. And using my phone, even though I know it’s not great, at least distracts me for a little while. But then I end up staying up way too late, and I feel worse the next day. It just feels like I don’t have control over it.

It sounds like the racing thoughts feel relentless and using your phone becomes a way to get some relief, even though it ends up making things harder. Feeling like it’s out of your control must be frustrating and draining. It makes sense why you’d turn to something that can distract you, even briefly, when you’re in that moment. What do you think control would look like for you when it comes to managing those thoughts or sleep?

I think control would mean being able to quiet my mind enough to fall asleep without needing to distract myself. Maybe feeling like I can stop the spiral of worry before it takes over. It just feels so far removed from where I’m at right now, though.

Quieting your mind and stopping the spiral sounds like a hopeful vision, even though it feels distant right now. Having that level of control could create space for rest and even reconnecting with things like your family that matter to you. It can be really overwhelming when it seems out of reach, but the fact that you’re articulating what you’d like is a meaningful step. What do you think is keeping that vision from feeling possible at the moment?

I think it's just how constant everything feels. The stress at work isn’t going away, the worries about my family keep piling on, and I don’t have a way to shut it all down. It’s hard to imagine being able to calm my mind when the problems feel so big and out of my control.

It sounds like the weight of everything right now feels nonstop, and when the problems seem so big and outside your control, it's hard to even imagine calming your mind. It’s a lot to carry, and it’s understandable that finding peace feels challenging in the midst of it all. Even with everything feeling constant, you’ve been showing resilience in sharing where you’re at and considering ways to move forward. What’s helped you get through stressful times in the past?

I’m honestly not sure. I don’t think I’ve ever felt this level of stress, at least not for this long. In the past, I’ve just pushed through things, but it doesn’t feel like that’s working anymore. There’s too much happening all at once.

It sounds like you’ve always relied on pushing through difficult times, but this stress feels like more than you’ve faced before—like it’s building up and becoming overwhelming. Recognizing that your old way of coping doesn’t feel effective anymore is significant, even if it’s hard. It shows you’re reflecting on what you need now rather than just trying to power through. What do you feel you might need to handle things differently this time?

Honestly, I don’t really know. I feel like I’ve been running on empty for so long that I don’t even know what would help anymore. Maybe I just need someone to tell me what to do because I can’t seem to figure it out on my own.

It sounds like you’re feeling really drained right now, and trying to figure it out on your own has been overwhelming, especially since it feels like nothing has been working. Wanting someone to guide you through this makes a lot of sense when you’re carrying so much. If you’re open to it, reaching out to a professional, like a counselor or therapist, might give you the extra support you’re looking for during this tough time. What are your thoughts about that idea?

I don’t know... Honestly, I’m hesitant about the idea of seeing someone else. I guess I just don’t know what they could do that I haven’t already tried on my own. But at the same time, I’m talking to you now, so maybe it’s worth considering if it could actually help.

Your hesitation is completely understandable—after trying things on your own, it’s only natural to wonder if talking to someone else could truly make a difference. At the same time, it’s encouraging that you’re here exploring the idea, showing that you’re open to possibilities. Taking that first step can sometimes lead to unexpected ways of managing things, especially when the challenges feel overwhelming. What would make you feel more comfortable about considering professional support?
